Tuchel was pleased with the majority of our play but felt we were lacking that killer instinct in the final third.

‘I think today was a high quality game between two very strong teams,’ said Thomas at the final whistle.

We take we have got today [a point]. Overall, I am very happy with the performance and the determination of the team but we need to be more clinical. Against a team like Manchester United, you don’t get many chances, so you have to take them when they come along.

‘Right now we are not in the moment where we are clinical enough to win these games that are evenly poised, but if we continue in this way we will get to that point I am sure.’

æœï¼šå””çŸ¥check [var]åšŸåšä¹œï¼

United didn’t test our goal on too many occasions but the big talking point came in the first half, where VAR was used to check a possible handball in the area from Callum Hudson-Odoi.

After consulting the monitor and watching the incident back, the referee stuck with his initial decision not to award a penalty and our head coach admitted he couldn’t understand why a VAR check was even needed in the first place.

‘I don’t know why we had to check VAR for the penalty decision,’ Tuchel added.

‘In my opinion, the referee did everything right. The Manchester United player [Greenwood] plays it with his hand. I saw this in real time and I saw it again on the iPad. There was no need to check this on the monitor and the referee got the decision totally right to begin with.

‘I don’t know why he was told to check it but I am glad it wasn’t given as a penalty because that would be even worse!’
